choices.text: The presence of postictal weakness suggests a diagnosis of functional (psychogenic) seizures.
The seizure is likely to generalize, as focal seizures always progress to bilateral tonic-clonic seizures.
This type of seizure is commonly associated with underlying structural brain lesions.
Since the patient remains conscious, this is classified as a generalized seizure.

questions.text: A 42-year-old right-handed man presents with recurrent episodes of involuntary movements of his right hand, lasting for about 30 seconds, followed by transient weakness in the same hand. He remains fully conscious during these episodes. EEG shows epileptiform discharges over the left precentral gyrus. Which of the following statements is TRUE regarding his condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

This type of seizure is commonly associated with underlying structural brain lesions.

Explanation:
•    The patient has focal motor seizures with postictal weakness (Todd's paresis), which suggests an epileptogenic focus in the motor cortex (precentral gyrus).
•    Option A is incorrect: Postictal weakness (Todd's paresis) is a hallmark of focal-onset motor seizures, not psychogenic seizures.
•    Option B is incorrect: Focal seizures can remain localized, evolve into focal seizures with impaired awareness, or generalize. Not all focal seizures generalize.
•    Option C is correct: Focal seizures, especially motor seizures, are commonly associated with underlying structural abnormalities (e.g., stroke, tumors, cortical dysplasia).
•    Option D is incorrect: The seizure is focal, not generalized, since consciousness is preserved and the manifestations are localized.

choices.text: JME accounts for less than 1% of all epilepsies and is rarely genetic.
It typically presents in early childhood with focal seizures and behavioral abnormalities.
EEG shows generalized 3 Hz spike-and-wave discharges, similar to childhood absence epilepsy.
Valproate is the most effective treatment but may not be the first choice in women of childbearing age.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is TRUE regarding juvenile myoclonic epilepsy (JME)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Valproate is the most effective treatment but may not be the first choice in women of childbearing age.
Explanation:
•    
•    Option A is incorrect: JME accounts for 5–10% of all epilepsies and has a strong genetic predisposition, often inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern with variable penetrance.

•    Option B is incorrect: JME typically presents in adolescence (between 12–18 years of age) with myoclonic jerks, often occurring in the morning. Focal seizures are not characteristic.
•    Option C is incorrect: The classic EEG finding in JME is generalized 4–6 Hz polyspike-and-wave discharges, not the 3 Hz spike-and-wave pattern seen in childhood absence epilepsy.
•    Option D is correct: Valproate is the most effective first-line treatment, but it is avoided in women of childbearing age due to its teratogenic effects (risk of neural tube defects and cognitive impairment in offspring). Alternatives like levetiracetam is preferred in these cases.

choices.text: Women with epilepsy have an increased risk of preeclampsia and fetal growth restriction.
Lamotrigine levels remain stable throughout pregnancy, requiring no dose adjustments.
Valproate is preferred over levetiracetam in pregnancy due to its superior seizure control.
Breastfeeding is contraindicated in women taking antiepileptic drugs (AEDs).

questions.text: Which of the following statements is TRUE regarding epilepsy management during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Women with epilepsy have an increased risk of preeclampsia and fetal growth restriction.
Explanation:
•    Option A is correct: Women with epilepsy have a higher risk of pregnancy complications, including preeclampsia, fetal growth restriction, preterm labor, and increased perinatal mortality.

•    Option B is incorrect: Lamotrigine levels decrease significantly during pregnancy due to increased hepatic metabolism and renal clearance, often requiring dose adjustments to maintain seizure control.
•    Option C is incorrect: Valproate is highly teratogenic (risk of neural tube defects, cognitive impairment, and autism), and should be avoided in pregnancy unless no other option is effective. Levetiracetam is preferred due to a better safety profile.
•    Option D is incorrect: Breastfeeding is generally safe for women taking AEDs, as most drugs (except phenobarbital and primidone in high doses) have minimal effects on the infant. The benefits of breastfeeding outweigh potential risks.

choices.text: Athetosis
Hemiballismus
Chorea
Dystonia

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes presents with sudden, violent, flinging movements of his right arm and leg that started a few hours ago. He has no prior history of movement disorders. MRI brain shows a small infarct in the left subthalamic nucleus. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Hemiballismus
Explanation:
•    Option A (Athetosis) is incorrect: Athetosis is characterized by slow, writhing, involuntary movements, usually affecting the hands and fingers. It is commonly seen in conditions like cerebral palsy due lesion in Globus Pallidus, but it is not sudden in onset and does not present with violent flinging movements.
•    Option B (Hemiballismus) is correct: Hemiballismus is caused by damage to the contralateral subthalamic nucleus, typically due to a stroke. It presents as sudden, large-amplitude, flinging movements of one side of the body (proximal limbs). This matches the patient’s symptoms.
•    Option C (Chorea) is incorrect: Chorea consists of random, flowing, dance-like movements that are more continuous and less violent than hemiballismus. It occurs due to lesion in caudate nucleus.
•    Option D (Dystonia) is incorrect: Dystonia involves sustained muscle contractions causing abnormal postures or repetitive twisting movements, often worsened by voluntary movement. It is not typically caused by an acute stroke.

choices.text: Cerebellar ataxia due to spinocerebellar degeneration
Proximal muscle weakness due to muscular dystrophy
Parkinson’s disease leading to postural instability
Stroke affecting the corticospinal tract

questions.text: 35-year-old woman presents with progressive difficulty walking over the past year. She reports frequent falls and difficulty climbing stairs. On examination, she has a wide-based, rolling gait with excessive trunk sway. Hip abductor weakness is noted on the Trendelenburg test, and serum creatine kinase (CK) is elevated. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her gait abnormality?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Proximal muscle weakness due to muscular dystrophy
Explanation:
•    Option A (Cerebellar ataxia) is incorrect: Cerebellar disorders cause broad-based, unsteady gait with dysmetria and intention tremor. The Trendelenburg sign and high CK levels are not seen in cerebellar ataxia.
•    Option B (Correct Answer – Muscular Dystrophy): Waddling gait is a classic sign of proximal muscle weakness, often seen in muscular dystrophies (Duchenne, Becker, or limb-girdle muscular dystrophy). The Trendelenburg sign (pelvic drop due to weak hip abductors) and elevated CK suggest muscle disease.
•    Option C (Parkinson’s disease) is incorrect: Parkinsonian gait is shuffling with festination, not waddling. Patients have rigidity, tremor, and postural instability, but no proximal muscle weakness.
•    Option D (Stroke) is incorrect: A stroke affecting the corticospinal tract typically causes a hemiparetic (circumduction) gait rather than a waddling gait.

choices.text: It is the second most common neurodegenerative disorder after Alzheimer’s disease and primarily affects the cerebellum.
The characteristic resting tremor of PD is typically high-frequency (8–12 Hz) and worsens with movement.
Parkinsonian gait is characterized by shuffling steps, reduced arm swing, and festination due to postural instability.
Levodopa is avoided in early disease due to its lack of efficacy and is only used in advanced Parkinson’s disease.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is TRUE regarding Parkinson’s disease (PD)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Parkinsonian gait is characterized by shuffling steps, reduced arm swing, and festination due to postural instability.
________________________________________
Explanation:
•    Option A (Incorrect): Parkinson’s disease is the second most common neurodegenerative disorder, but it primarily affects the basal ganglia (substantia nigra), not the cerebellum. The loss of dopaminergic neurons leads to motor symptoms.
•    Option B (Incorrect): The resting tremor in Parkinson’s disease is low-frequency (4–6 Hz) and classically described as a "pill-rolling" tremor. It improves with voluntary movement and worsens at rest.
•    Option C (Correct): Parkinsonian gait is shuffling with reduced arm swing, difficulty initiating movement, festination (involuntary acceleration), and postural instability—a hallmark feature of PD.
•    Option D (Incorrect): Levodopa is the most effective treatment for Parkinson’s disease and is often used early. However, long-term use can lead to motor fluctuations and dyskinesias, so younger patients may initially be managed with dopamine agonists (e.g., pramipexole, ropinirole).

choices.text: Hemispatial neglect is equally common with left and right hemisphere lesions.
Patients with left-sided neglect typically have a lesion in the left parietal lobe.
Hemispatial neglect can be fully corrected by simply instructing the patient to pay attention to the neglected side.
Hemispatial neglect is most often associated with a lesion in the right parietal lobe, leading to left-sided inattention.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man who recently had a right middle cerebral artery stroke is observed to ignore stimuli on the left side of his visual field. When asked to draw a clock, he only fills in the numbers on the right half. Which of the following statements is TRUE regarding his condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Hemispatial neglect is most often associated with a lesion in the right parietal lobe, leading to left-sided inattention.
________________________________________
Explanation:
•    Option A is incorrect: Hemispatial neglect is significantly more common and more severe with right hemisphere lesions (usually in the right inferior parietal lobe), causing left-sided neglect.
•    Option B is incorrect: While left parietal lesions can sometimes cause right-sided neglect, the classic and more pronounced form is left-sided neglect following a right parietal lesion.
•    Option C is incorrect: Merely instructing the patient to pay attention to the neglected side rarely completely resolves neglect. Patients often need intensive rehabilitation, visual scanning strategies, and other specialized therapies.
•    Option D is correct: The right parietal lobe is crucial for attentional processing of both sides of space, so a lesion here often results in left hemispatial neglect.
Tough MCQ on Posterior Cerebral Artery (PCA) Infarction

choices.text: Left middle cerebral artery (MCA) infarction involving the parietal lobe
Left posterior cerebral artery (PCA) infarction involving the occipital lobe and splenium of the corpus callosum
Right middle cerebral artery (MCA) infarction affecting the inferior frontal gyrus
Right anterior cerebral artery (ACA) infarction affecting the medial frontal lobe

questions.text: A 68-year-old right-handed man with a history of hypertension and atrial fibrillation presents with sudden-onset difficulty seeing objects on his right side and trouble reading words but can still write normally. He also struggles to recognize familiar faces and appears confused when asked about objects in his right visual field. Neurological examination reveals right homonymous hemianopia but no motor weakness. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Left posterior cerebral artery (PCA) infarction involving the occipital lobe and splenium of the corpus callosum
________________________________________
Explanation:
•    Option A (Left MCA infarct) is incorrect: MCA strokes typically cause contralateral motor and sensory deficits, often with aphasia (if left-sided) or spatial neglect (if right-sided). This patient’s pure visual deficits and alexia without agraphia suggest PCA involvement instead of MCA.
•    Option B (Correct – Left PCA infarct): 
o    Right homonymous hemianopia → Occipital lobe involvement.
o    Alexia without agraphia → Damage to the splenium of the corpus callosum, preventing visual information from reaching the left language areas.
o    Prosopagnosia (face blindness) → Inferior temporal lobe (fusiform gyrus) involvement.
o    No motor weakness → PCA infarcts spare the motor cortex, which is supplied by the MCA.
•    Option C (Right MCA infarct) is incorrect: MCA infarcts cause contralateral motor deficits, aphasia (left hemisphere), or hemispatial neglect (right hemisphere). The absence of motor symptoms and the presence of alexia without agraphia rule out an MCA stroke.
•    Option D (Right ACA infarct) is incorrect: ACA strokes typically cause contralateral leg weakness and behavioral changes, but do not cause visual deficits.
Case-Based Tough MCQ on Aphasia

choices.text: Broca’s aphasia
Transcortical motor aphasia
Wernicke’s aphasia
Conduction aphasia

questions.text: A 62-year-old right-handed man presents to the emergency department after a stroke. His speech is fluent but nonsensical, and he frequently substitutes incorrect words (paraphasias). He does not follow commands and seems unaware of his language deficits.Patient cannot repeat phrases correctly . Neurological examination reveals no motor deficits. Which of the following is the most likely type of aphasia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Wernicke’s aphasia 
________________________________________
Explanation:
•    Option A (Broca’s aphasia) is incorrect: Broca’s aphasia presents with non-fluent, effortful speech, good comprehension, and poor repetition. This patient has fluent but nonsensical speech, which rules out Broca’s aphasia.
•    Option B (Transcortical motor aphasia) is incorrect: Transcortical motor aphasia presents with non-fluent speech but intact repetition, which does not match this case.
•    Option C (Correct – Wernicke’s aphasia): 
o    Fluent speech but lacks meaning (word salad, paraphasias).
o    Poor comprehension (unable to follow commands).
o    Impaired repetition (damage to Wernicke’s area in the dominant superior temporal gyrus).
o    Lack of awareness (anosognosia is common in Wernicke’s aphasia).
•    Option D (Conduction aphasia) is incorrect: While conduction aphasia also has fluent speech and poor repetition, it presents with good comprehension, which this patient lacks.

choices.text: The gait disturbance in NPH is due to damage to the corticospinal tract.
High-volume lumbar puncture (CSF tap test) can transiently improve symptoms.
The memory deficits in NPH are typically irreversible and worsen despite treatment.
Ventriculomegaly in NPH is always associated with elevated intracranial pressure.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Normal Pressure Hydrocephalus (NPH) condition is TRUE?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

High-volume lumbar puncture (CSF tap test) can transiently improve symptoms.
________________________________________
Explanation:
•    Option A (Incorrect): The gait disturbance in NPH is due to distortion of periventricular white matter, particularly affecting frontal lobe pathways, not corticospinal tract damage. This leads to the classic "magnetic gait" where feet appear stuck to the floor.
•    Option B (Correct Answer): A high-volume lumbar puncture (CSF tap test) temporarily relieves symptoms by removing 30–50 mL of CSF, confirming the diagnosis. Definitive treatment is a ventriculoperitoneal (VP) shunt, which can lead to long-term improvement.
•    Option C (Incorrect): Cognitive impairment in NPH is potentially reversible if treated early. Unlike Alzheimer’s disease, which causes progressive and irreversible memory loss, VP shunting can significantly improve cognitive function in NPH.
•    Option D (Incorrect): NPH is a communicating hydrocephalus, meaning intracranial pressure remains within normal limits despite ventriculomegaly. The exact cause of impaired CSF absorption is not always known, but chronic CSF accumulation leads to periventricular white matter dysfunction.

choices.text: The incidence of Alzheimer's disease is highest in individuals aged 50-60 years.
Early personality changes and behavioral disinhibition are more common than memory impairment in Alzheimer's disease.
Postmortem biopsy typically reveals neurofibrillary tangles composed of hyperphosphorylated tau and extracellular β-amyloid plaques.
Cholinesterase inhibitors, such as rivastigmine, can reverse the neuronal degeneration seen in Alzheimer's disease.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding Alzheimer's disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Postmortem biopsy typically reveals neurofibrillary tangles composed of hyperphosphorylated tau and extracellular β-amyloid plaques.
•    The hallmark histopathological findings of Alzheimer's disease include neurofibrillary tangles (tau protein) and senile plaques (β-amyloid). These are seen on autopsy and contribute to neuronal degeneration.

•    A. Incorrect. The incidence of Alzheimer's disease increases with age, particularly after 65 years. The highest risk is in those >85 years old, not 50-60 years.
•    B. Incorrect. Early personality and behavioral changes are more characteristic of frontotemporal dementia (FTD) rather than Alzheimer's, where memory impairment is the initial and most prominent feature.
•    D. Incorrect. Cholinesterase inhibitors (e.g., donepezil, rivastigmine, galantamine) provide symptomatic relief but do not reverse neuronal degeneration. They help slow cognitive decline but do not cure the disease.

choices.text: The underlying pathology of frontotemporal dementia involves tau protein and TDP-43 inclusions.
Memory impairment is the earliest and most prominent feature of frontotemporal dementia.
Cholinesterase inhibitors such as donepezil are the first-line treatment for frontotemporal dementia.
The incidence of frontotemporal dementia is highest in individuals older than 80 years.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most accurate statement regarding Fronto temporal dementia (FTD) ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The underlying pathology of frontotemporal dementia involves tau protein and TDP-43 inclusions.
•    Frontotemporal dementia (FTD) is associated with abnormal tau protein (Pick bodies in Pick disease) and TDP-43 inclusions (in some subtypes). These contribute to neurodegeneration in the frontal and temporal lobes, leading to behavioral and language dysfunction.

•    B. Incorrect. Unlike Alzheimer's disease, where memory loss is the earliest symptom, FTD primarily affects behavior, personality, and language before memory impairment becomes significant.
•    C. Incorrect. Cholinesterase inhibitors (e.g., donepezil, rivastigmine) are not effective in FTD, as the disease primarily affects the frontal lobes rather than cholinergic pathways. There is no approved disease-modifying treatment for FTD.
•    D. Incorrect. FTD typically presents earlier than Alzheimer's, often between 40-65 years of age (younger onset dementia), making it a leading cause of early-onset dementia, rather than a disease of the elderly (>80 years).

choices.text: Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) is caused by a newly acquired JC virus infection in immunocompromised individuals.
PML primarily affects the gray matter, leading to cortical atrophy and neuronal loss.
Contrast enhancement and significant perilesional edema are common findings in PML brain lesions.
The primary management of PML in an HIV-positive patient involves immune reconstitution with antiretroviral therapy (ART).

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy is most accurate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The primary management of PML in an HIV-positive patient involves immune reconstitution with antiretroviral therapy (ART).
•    PML is caused by reactivation of JC virus in immunocompromised individuals (e.g., HIV/AIDS, transplant recipients, patients on natalizumab).
•    There is no specific antiviral treatment, but immune reconstitution with ART is the best approach in HIV patients, as it improves immune function and can lead to stabilization or partial recovery.

•    A. Incorrect. PML is not due to new JC virus infection, but rather reactivation of a latent JC virus in immunocompromised individuals. Most people acquire JC virus in childhood, and it remains dormant until immunity declines.
•    B. Incorrect. PML is a white matter disease, affecting oligodendrocytes and leading to demyelination. The gray matter is typically spared.
•    C. Incorrect. Unlike other CNS infections or malignancies, PML does not typically show contrast enhancement or significant perilesional edema on MRI. The lesions are non-enhancing, which helps distinguish PML from CNS lymphoma.
MCQ on Charcot-Marie-Tooth Disease (CMT) - Identifying Incorrect Statement

choices.text: CMT is a hereditary peripheral neuropathy that primarily affects the distal muscles of the lower extremities before involving the upper extremities.
CMT primarily affects the central nervous system, leading to upper motor neuron signs such as spasticity and hyperreflexia.
The disease can be classified into demyelinating (CMT1) and axonal (CMT2) subtypes, with nerve conduction studies helping to differentiate them.
Common clinical features include foot drop, pes cavus, hammer toes, and distal muscle atrophy, often leading to a "stork-leg" appearance.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease (CMT) is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

CMT primarily affects the central nervous system, leading to upper motor neuron signs such as spasticity and hyperreflexia. (Incorrect Statement)
•    CMT is not a central nervous system disorder; it is a peripheral neuropathy that primarily affects the peripheral nerves, leading to lower motor neuron signs such as distal muscle weakness, atrophy, foot deformities, and reduced reflexes.
•    It does not cause spasticity, hyperreflexia, or other upper motor neuron signs, which are seen in conditions affecting the central nervous system (e.g., ALS, multiple sclerosis).
•    A.  CMT typically starts with distal muscle weakness in the lower extremities (leading to foot drop, high-arched feet) before progressing to the hands and forearms.
•    C.  CMT has two major subtypes: 
o    CMT1 (demyelinating) – characterized by slow conduction velocity on nerve conduction studies.
o    CMT2 (axonal) – characterized by normal or mildly reduced conduction velocity with reduced amplitude.
•    D.  Foot drop, pes cavus (high-arched foot), hammer toes, and distal muscle wasting ("stork-leg" appearance) are hallmark features of CMT.

choices.text: Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS) is caused by direct invasion of the peripheral nerves by Campylobacter jejuni.
Corticosteroids are the first-line treatment for Guillain-Barré Syndrome.
The pathophysiology of Guillain-Barré Syndrome involves an immune-mediated attack on myelin or axons of the peripheral nervous system.
Patients with GBS typically present with an ascending weakness, hyperreflexia, and upper motor neuron signs.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most accurate statement regarding Gullain Barre syndrome (GBS) ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The pathophysiology of Guillain-Barré Syndrome involves an immune-mediated attack on myelin or axons of the peripheral nervous system.
•    GBS is an autoimmune disorder where antibodies (often triggered by infections like Campylobacter jejuni) target peripheral nerve myelin (AIDP subtype) or axons (AMAN subtype), leading to acute inflammatory demyelination or axonal damage.
•    This results in rapidly progressive ascending weakness, areflexia, and variable sensory symptoms.

•    A. Incorrect. Campylobacter jejuni is a common trigger for GBS, but the bacterium does not directly invade the nerves. Instead, molecular mimicry leads to an immune attack on peripheral nerves.
•    B. Incorrect. Corticosteroids are not effective in GBS and are not recommended for treatment. Instead, plasmapheresis or intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) is used.
•    D. Incorrect. GBS is a peripheral nerve disorder, leading to lower motor neuron signs such as areflexia and flaccid paralysis, not hyperreflexia or upper motor neuron signs.

choices.text: The most common type of Multiple Sclerosis is Primary Progressive MS (PPMS), which accounts for the majority of cases.
Common clinical features of MS include optic neuritis, internuclear ophthalmoplegia, spasticity, and urinary incontinence.
MRI with contrast is the investigation of choice and typically shows periventricular white matter lesions, Dawson’s fingers, and enhancing plaques in active disease.
Disease-modifying therapies such as Natalizumab, Fingolimod, and Ocrelizumab are used to reduce the frequency and severity of MS relapses.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Multiple Sclerosis (MS) is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The most common type of Multiple Sclerosis is Primary Progressive MS (PPMS), which accounts for the majority of cases. (Incorrect Statement)
•    The most common type of MS is Relapsing MS (RMS), which accounts for ~90% of cases.
•    Primary Progressive MS (PPMS) accounts for only ~10 of cases and is characterized by gradual neurological decline without distinct relapses or remissions.

B. Correct. MS has a wide range of clinical symptoms including: 
o    Optic neuritis (painful vision loss, afferent pupillary defect)
o    Internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO) (due to MLF lesion, causing impaired adduction)
o    Spasticity, limb weakness, sensory deficits
o    Bladder dysfunction (e.g., urinary incontinence, urgency)
•    C. Correct. MRI is the gold standard for MS diagnosis, showing: 
o    Periventricular white matter lesions
o    Dawson’s fingers (lesions extending radially from the ventricles)
o    Gadolinium-enhancing plaques in active disease
•    D. Correct. Disease-modifying therapies such as Natalizumab (anti-VLA-4), Fingolimod (S1P receptor modulator), and Ocrelizumab (anti-CD20) help in reducing the frequency of relapses and slowing disease progression in MS.

choices.text: Migraine aura is caused by vascular occlusion leading to transient ischemia in the occipital cortex.
The presence of a migraine aura significantly reduces the risk of stroke in affected individuals.
Beta-blockers and triptans are equally effective in aborting an acute migraine attack.
Triptans are contraindicated in patients with uncontrolled hypertension or ischemic heart disease.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding migraine is most accurate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Triptans are contraindicated in patients with uncontrolled hypertension or ischemic heart disease.
•    Triptans (e.g., sumatriptan, rizatriptan) are serotonin (5-HT1B/1D) receptor agonists that cause vasoconstriction to abort migraines.
•    They are contraindicated in patients with uncontrolled hypertension, coronary artery disease, or a history of stroke, due to the risk of vasospasm and ischemic events.
A. Incorrect. Migraine aura is caused by cortical spreading depression, a wave of neuronal depolarization followed by suppression, not vascular occlusion or ischemia.
•    B. Incorrect. Having a migraine with aura increases the risk of ischemic stroke, particularly in young women who smoke or use estrogen-containing oral contraceptives.
•    C. Incorrect. Beta-blockers (e.g., propranolol) are used for migraine prophylaxis, whereas triptans are used for acute treatment. Triptans are more effective for aborting attacks than beta-blockers, which do not provide immediate relief.

choices.text: Myasthenia Gravis is caused by a deficiency of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction, leading to reduced muscle activation.
The presence of hyporeflexia and autonomic dysfunction is a hallmark of Myasthenia Gravis.
The diagnosis of Myasthenia Gravis can be confirmed by detecting anti-acetylcholine receptor (AChR) antibodies and electrophysiological testing.
First-line treatment for Myasthenia Gravis includes corticosteroids and rituximab, while acetylcholinesterase inhibitors have no role in management.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Myasthenia Gravis is most accurate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The diagnosis of Myasthenia Gravis can be confirmed by detecting anti-acetylcholine receptor (AChR) antibodies and electrophysiological testing.
•    Serologic testing for anti-AChR antibodies (or anti-MuSK antibodies in some cases) confirms MG in most patients.
•    Electrophysiological studies (repetitive nerve stimulation or single-fiber EMG) show decremental response and impaired neuromuscular transmission.
•    A. Incorrect. MG is caused by autoantibodies against acetylcholine receptors, not acetylcholine deficiency. The antibodies block, degrade, or destroy the receptors, leading to reduced muscle activation.
•    B. Incorrect. MG does not cause autonomic dysfunction or hyporeflexia. In contrast, Lambert-Eaton Myasthenic Syndrome (LEMS) presents with hyporeflexia and autonomic dysfunction (e.g., dry mouth, erectile dysfunction).
•    D. Incorrect. Acetylcholinesterase inhibitors (e.g., pyridostigmine) are first-line symptomatic treatment. Immunotherapy (e.g., corticosteroids, rituximab) is used for long-term control in severe or refractory cases.

choices.text: Complete spinal cord transection at T10
Left-sided hemisection of the spinal cord at T10
Right-sided lesion affecting only the corticospinal tract at T10
Right-sided hemisection of the spinal cord at T10

questions.text: A 40-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after sustaining a knife injury to the right side of his lower back at the T10 level. He complains of weakness in his right leg and altered sensation in both legs. On neurological examination, the following findings are noted: • Right leg (ipsilateral to injury): o Spastic paralysis with hyperreflexia o Loss of vibration and proprioception • Left leg (contralateral to injury): o Loss of pain and temperature sensation, beginning at T12 Which of the following best explains the patient's neurological deficits?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Right-sided hemisection of the spinal cord at T10
•    This patient presents with Brown-Séquard Syndrome, which results from spinal cord hemisection (half of the cord being damaged), often due to penetrating trauma.
•    The deficits follow a characteristic pattern based on the affected tracts:
Ipsilateral (Right side) Below T10:
o    Corticospinal tract damage → spastic paralysis (upper motor neuron signs)
o    Dorsal column damage → loss of proprioception and vibration
Contralateral (Left side) Below T12:
o    Spinothalamic tract damage → loss of pain and temperature sensation (which starts 1–2 levels below the lesion due to decussation at the spinal level).
________________________________________

•    A. Incorrect. A complete spinal cord transection would cause bilateral motor and sensory loss below T10, not an asymmetric pattern.
•    B. Incorrect. A left-sided hemisection would cause ipsilateral deficits on the left and contralateral deficits on the right, opposite to this patient’s presentation.
•    C. Incorrect. A right-sided corticospinal tract lesion alone would cause only motor weakness, but would not explain the sensory deficits.

choices.text: It is caused by occlusion of the anterior spinal artery.
It presents with ipsilateral Horner’s syndrome.
It causes contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation in the body.
Hoarseness and dysphagia occur due to nucleus ambiguus involvement.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Lateral Medullary Syndrome (Wallenberg Syndrome) is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

It is caused by occlusion of the anterior spinal artery. (Incorrect Statement)
•    Lateral Medullary Syndrome is caused by occlusion of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA) or the vertebral artery, NOT the anterior spinal artery.
•    The anterior spinal artery occlusion affects the medial medulla (not lateral) and leads to medial medullary syndrome (Dejerine syndrome), which presents with contralateral hemiparesis, contralateral loss of proprioception/vibration, and ipsilateral tongue deviation.

•    B. Correct. Ipsilateral Horner’s syndrome (ptosis, miosis) occurs due to disruption of the descending sympathetic fibers.
•    C. Correct. Contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation in the body occurs due to spinothalamic tract involvement.
•    D. Correct. Hoarseness and dysphagia occur due to nucleus ambiguus (CN IX, X) involvement, a hallmark of lateral medullary syndrome.

choices.text: Prolactinomas rarely cause galactorrhea or menstrual irregularities in premenopausal women.
Surgical resection is the first-line therapy for all prolactinomas, regardless of size.
High prolactin levels are unaffected by dopamine agonists, making medical management ineffective.
Prolactinomas are the most common type of functioning pituitary adenoma.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding prolactinomas is most accurate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Prolactinomas are the most common type of functioning pituitary adenoma.
•    Among the functioning (hormone-secreting) pituitary tumors, prolactinomas account for the largest proportion. They often present with amenorrhea, galactorrhea, and sometimes reduced libido or erectile dysfunction in men.
________________________________________
Why the Other Options Are Incorrect:
•    A. Incorrect. Prolactinomas commonly present with galactorrhea and menstrual irregularities (e.g., amenorrhea) in premenopausal women.
•    B. Incorrect. Medical management with dopamine agonists (e.g., bromocriptine, cabergoline) is typically the first-line treatment, especially for microadenomas. Surgery is usually reserved for those who fail or cannot tolerate medical therapy.
•    C. Incorrect. Dopamine agonists effectively lower prolactin levels and can reduce tumor size; they are the cornerstone of therapy for prolactinomas.

choices.text: Acromegaly is most commonly caused by ectopic growth hormone (GH) secretion from a non-pituitary tumor.
Excess GH leads to insulin resistance, increasing the risk of diabetes mellitus.
IGF-1 (Insulin-like Growth Factor 1) is the most reliable diagnostic marker for acromegaly.
Transsphenoidal surgery is the first-line treatment for most GH-secreting pituitary adenomas.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding acromegaly is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Acromegaly is most commonly caused by ectopic growth hormone (GH) secretion from a non-pituitary tumor. (Incorrect Statement)
•    Acromegaly is most commonly caused by a pituitary adenoma secreting excess GH, not an ectopic tumor.
•    Ectopic GH secretion from non-pituitary tumors is rare, though ectopic GHRH secretion (from neuroendocrine tumors) can stimulate GH production.
________________________________________
•    B. Correct. GH increases hepatic gluconeogenesis and lipolysis, leading to insulin resistance and an increased risk of diabetes mellitus.
•    C. Correct. IGF-1 measurement is the most reliable diagnostic marker for acromegaly since it reflects chronic GH secretion and is not subject to daily fluctuations like GH itself.
•    D. Correct. Transsphenoidal surgery is the first-line treatment for GH-secreting pituitary adenomas, particularly in patients with macroadenomas causing mass effect.

choices.text: Central Diabetes Insipidus
Nephrogenic Diabetes Insipidus
Psychogenic Polydipsia
Syndrome of Inappropriate Antidiuretic Hormone Secretion (SIADH)

questions.text: A 40-year-old man with a history of head trauma six months ago presents with a 3-month history of excessive urination (producing over 10 liters of urine daily) and intense thirst. He reports frequent nocturia and difficulty maintaining hydration. Laboratory tests reveal: • Serum sodium: 150 mEq/L • Urine osmolality: 150 mOsm/kg A water deprivation test is performed, and his urine osmolality remains low. However, following administration of desmopressin, his urine osmolality increases by more than 50%. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Central Diabetes Insipidus
•    The patient’s history of head trauma, combined with polyuria, polydipsia, hypernatremia, and low urine osmolality, points toward a diagnosis of Diabetes Insipidus (DI).
•    The water deprivation test confirms that he cannot concentrate his urine. The significant improvement in urine osmolality after desmopressin administration indicates that the kidneys can respond to ADH, confirming Central Diabetes Insipidus (a deficiency of ADH production from the posterior pituitary).

•    B. Nephrogenic Diabetes Insipidus: In this condition, the kidneys do not respond to ADH, so desmopressin would not lead to a significant increase in urine osmolality.
•    C. Psychogenic Polydipsia: Patients with this condition typically have low serum sodium due to excessive water intake and are able to concentrate urine during a water deprivation test.
•    D. SIADH: This syndrome is characterized by water retention, hyponatremia, and concentrated urine, which is the opposite of the findings seen in this patient.

choices.text: SIADH is characterized by euvolemic hyponatremia with inappropriately concentrated urine.
Patients with SIADH typically have signs of volume overload, such as peripheral edema and pulmonary congestion.
Small cell lung cancer is a common paraneoplastic cause of SIADH.
Management includes fluid restriction, hypertonic saline for severe cases, and vasopressin receptor antagonists like tolvaptan.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Syndrome of Inappropriate Antidiuretic Hormone Secretion (SIADH) is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Patients with SIADH typically have signs of volume overload, such as peripheral edema and pulmonary congestion. (Incorrect Statement)
•    SIADH causes euvolemic hyponatremia, meaning there is no peripheral edema or signs of overt volume overload.
•    Although water retention occurs, the RAAS system is suppressed, leading to natriuresis (increased sodium excretion) and maintaining a normal extracellular fluid volume.
________________________________________
•    A. Correct. SIADH causes euvolemic hyponatremia with inappropriately high urine osmolality (>100 mOsm/kg) despite low plasma osmolality.
•    C. Correct. Small cell lung cancer is a well-known cause of paraneoplastic SIADH, leading to excessive ADH secretion and water retention.
•    D. Correct. Management includes: 
o    Fluid restriction (first-line treatment).
o    Hypertonic saline (3%) in severe hyponatremia.
o    Vasopressin receptor antagonists (e.g., tolvaptan, conivaptan) in refractory cases.

choices.text: Pituitary adenoma (Cushing disease)
Adrenal adenoma
Exogenous steroid use
Ectopic ACTH production

questions.text: Which of the following most likely explains a Cushing syndrome patient with markedly elevated ACTH and no suppression on high-dose dexamethasone test?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Ectopic ACTH production
•    In Cushing syndrome with high ACTH and no suppression on high-dose dexamethasone, an ectopic source (e.g., small cell lung cancer) is most likely.
•    A pituitary adenoma (Cushing disease) typically shows partial or complete suppression with high-dose dexamethasone.
•    Adrenal adenomas cause low ACTH (due to negative feedback).
•    Exogenous steroids also suppress ACTH, leading to low endogenous cortisol production.

choices.text: Aldosterone-producing adrenal adenoma
Excessive renin secretion due to renal artery stenosis
Ectopic aldosterone secretion from a non-adrenal tumor
Pituitary adenoma secreting ACTH

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with refractory hypertension, muscle weakness, and frequent episodes of nocturia. Laboratory findings reveal hypokalemia with metabolic alkalosis. Further evaluation shows elevated plasma aldosterone and suppressed plasma renin activity. Which of the following best describes the underlying cause of her condition (Conn syndrome)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Aldosterone-producing adrenal adenoma
•    Conn syndrome refers to primary hyperaldosteronism, most commonly due to an aldosterone-producing adrenal adenoma.
•    Key features include hypertension, hypokalemia, metabolic alkalosis, and low renin.
•    Renin is suppressed because excess aldosterone increases sodium retention and fluid volume, reducing renin secretion via negative feedback.
________________________________________
Incorrect Answers
•    B. Excessive renin secretion due to renal artery stenosis: This would cause secondary hyperaldosteronism (high renin and high aldosterone).
•    C. Ectopic aldosterone secretion from a non-adrenal tumor is exceedingly rare and not the typical cause of Conn syndrome.
•    D. Pituitary adenoma secreting ACTH would lead to Cushing syndrome, not primary hyperaldosteronism.

choices.text: Tuberculous destruction of the adrenal glands
Metastatic cancer to the adrenal glands
Exogenous steroid withdrawal (secondary adrenal insufficiency)
Autoimmune destruction of the adrenal cortex

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman presents with chronic fatigue, weight loss, hyperpigmentation, and recurrent episodes of hypotension. Laboratory tests reveal hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and low morning cortisol levels. Her plasma ACTH is elevated. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her condition in developed countries?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Autoimmune destruction of the adrenal cortex

•    In developed countries, autoimmune adrenalitis (where the body’s immune system attacks the adrenal cortex) is the most common cause of primary adrenal insufficiency (Addison’s disease). This leads to deficient production of cortisol (and often aldosterone), resulting in fatigue, hypotension, hyponatremia, and hyperkalemia.
•    Hyperpigmentation occurs due to elevated ACTH, which shares a precursor (pro-opiomelanocortin, POMC) with melanocyte-stimulating hormone (MSH), promoting increased skin pigmentation.
•    A. Tuberculous destruction of the adrenal glands
o    In many developing countries, tuberculosis is a frequent cause of adrenal insufficiency. However, in developed countries, autoimmune causes predominate.
•    B. Metastatic cancer to the adrenal glands
o    While metastatic disease (particularly from lung or breast cancer) can affect the adrenal glands, it is less common than autoimmune destruction as a cause of Addison’s disease.
•    C. Exogenous steroid withdrawal (secondary adrenal insufficiency)
o    Abrupt discontinuation of long-term corticosteroids causes secondary (not primary) adrenal insufficiency, typically with low ACTH levels, and no significant hyperkalemia because aldosterone (mostly regulated by the renin-angiotensin system) remains intact.

choices.text: DKA is characterized by severe hyperglycemia, ketonemia, and an elevated anion gap metabolic acidosis.
Total body potassium is typically depleted, even if serum potassium appears normal or high on presentation.
Treatment focuses on intravenous fluids, insulin, and careful electrolyte replacement.
DKA is more common in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus than in those with type 1 diabetes mellitus.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Diabetic Ketoacidosis (DKA) is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

DKA is more common in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus than in those with type 1 diabetes mellitus.
•    DKA is most commonly associated with type 1 diabetes mellitus, where there is a profound insulin deficiency leading to lipolysis and ketogenesis. Although it can occur in type 2 diabetes under stress (e.g., infection), it is far less common compared to type 1.
________________________________________
•    A. DKA is indeed characterized by marked hyperglycemia (often >250 mg/dL), ketonemia, and an elevated anion gap metabolic acidosis (low bicarbonate, low pH, and increased anion gap).
•    B. Although the serum potassium may be normal or even elevated at presentation (due to an extracellular shift of potassium in acidotic states), the total body potassium is usually depleted because of urinary potassium losses from osmotic diuresis.
•    C. The mainstays of DKA management include aggressive fluid resuscitation, continuous IV insulin infusion, and electrolyte (especially potassium) replacement, while monitoring glucose, potassium, and acid-base status.

choices.text: Start liothyronine (T3) alone as it has a faster onset of action than levothyroxine.
Start levothyroxine at a high dose immediately to rapidly normalize thyroid levels.
Start levothyroxine at a weight-based dose and titrate based on TSH levels.
No treatment is needed since mild hypothyroidism does not require intervention.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman with a history of Hashimoto’s thyroiditis presents with fatigue, weight gain, cold intolerance, and dry skin. Laboratory tests reveal TSH: 12.5 mIU/L (elevated) and Free T4: low. She is diagnosed with primary hypothyroidism. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment strategy for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Start levothyroxine at a weight-based dose and titrate based on TSH levels.
•    Levothyroxine (T4) is the treatment of choice for hypothyroidism because it has a long half-life, allowing for once-daily dosing and stable thyroid hormone levels.
•    The initial dose is typically 1.6 mcg/kg/day, and TSH levels are monitored every 6–8 weeks to adjust the dose.
________________________________________

•    A. Liothyronine (T3) alone – Incorrect 
o    T3 has a short half-life and can cause fluctuations in hormone levels, leading to cardiac side effects (e.g., tachycardia). It is not used as monotherapy.
•    B. High-dose levothyroxine immediately – Incorrect 
o    Starting too high a dose can lead to cardiac complications, especially in older adults or those with heart disease. A gradual titration approach is safer.
•    D. No treatment is needed – Incorrect 
o    Even mild (subclinical) hypothyroidism may require treatment, particularly if the patient has symptoms, TSH >10 mIU/L, or is pregnant.

choices.text: It is characterized by resistance to parathyroid hormone (PTH) despite normal or elevated PTH levels.
Patients often present with hypocalcemia and hyperphosphatemia due to impaired PTH signaling.
Albright’s hereditary osteodystrophy (short stature, round face, brachydactyly) is associated with some forms of pseudohypoparathyroidism.
Calcium and phosphate levels normalize when exogenous PTH is administered.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding pseudohypoparathyroidism is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Calcium and phosphate levels normalize when exogenous PTH is administered. (Incorrect Statement)
•    Pseudohypoparathyroidism is due to end-organ resistance to PTH (typically a G-protein signaling defect).
•    Administering exogenous PTH does not correct hypocalcemia or hyperphosphatemia because the kidneys and bones are resistant to its effects.

•    A.  Pseudohypoparathyroidism is caused by PTH resistance, leading to elevated PTH levels but persistent hypocalcemia and hyperphosphatemia.
•    B.  Since the kidneys do not respond to PTH, phosphate excretion is impaired, leading to hyperphosphatemia.
•    C. Albright’s hereditary osteodystrophy (AHO) is associated with Pseudohypoparathyroidism type 1A, featuring short stature, round face, obesity, and shortened 4th/5th metacarpals (brachydactyly).

choices.text: Pre-Renal AKI
Glomerulonephritis
Tubulo-Interstitial disorders
Obstructive uropathy

questions.text: Non-Oliguric presentation of AKI is seen in
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Tubulo-Interstitial disorders

Due to loss of concentrating ability of the tubules, there is dilute polyuria in AKI due to tubule-interstitial disorders.

choices.text: Hypoalbuminemia
Anti-Thrombin III deficiency
Protein S & C deficiency
Sodium and H2O retention

questions.text: Anasarca in Nephrotic syndrome is due to
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Sodium & H2O retention

In Nephrotic syndrome, there is gross albuminuria leading to Hypoalbuminemia causing edema. In severe cases, there is RAAS activation due to intravascular dehydration leading to Sodium and H2O retention causing Anasarca. AT-III and Protein S,C deficiency leads to Hypercoagulable state.

choices.text: Fluid challenge
Inotrope support
Antibiotics
Stop drugs disrupting autoregulation

questions.text: Which is the first line treatment in a case of prerenal AKI?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Fluid challenge
Explanation: Prerenal AKI is often caused by conditions that reduce blood flow to the kidneys, such as hypovolemia (low blood volume) due to dehydration, blood loss, or severe heart failure, septic shock and rarely due to drugs disrupting autoregulation. Hence, the first line treatment is fluid challenge with Isotonic fluid like Normal saline.

choices.text: Serum creatinine
Urinalysis
Fractional excretion of sodium (FENa)
Blood urea nitrogen (BUN)

questions.text: Which diagnostic test is most useful in differentiating between prerenal and intrinsic renal causes of AKI?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Fractional excretion of sodium (FENa)
Explanation: FENa is a useful test to differentiate between prerenal and intrinsic renal causes of AKI. A FENa < 1% suggests prerenal AKI, while a FENa > 2% suggests intrinsic renal causes such as ATN.

choices.text: Osteomalacia is the most common type
Hypophosphatemia is found in majority cases
Correction of Mineral Homeostasis is first line treatment
Bed rest is advised

questions.text: Identify the true statement about CKD-associated Metabolic bone diseases
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Correction of Mineral Homeostasis is first line treatment
CKD-associated Metabolic Bone disease occurs in renal failure > 6 months. The most common type is Osteitis cystica fibrosa due to Hypocalcemia leading to hyperparathyroidism. Supplementation of Calcium, D3 and Lowering Phosphate is first line treatment. Encouraging Mobility prevent adynamic bone disease.

choices.text: Micro-albuminuria
Supranormal GFR
Shrunken kidneys
Thickening of the GBM

questions.text: Following are the findings in early stages of DM nephropathy EXCEPT
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Shrunken kidneys

IN early DM Nephropathy, there is supra normal GFR leading to Enlarged kidneys due to capillary hypertension. Micro-albuminuria is earliest finding. Renal Biopsy in early stages shows thickening of the GBM before progression to glomerulosclerosis.

choices.text: It is a selective mineralocorticoid receptor antagonist
Approved for preventing progression of CKD
Higher risk of hyperkalemia compared to Eplerenone
All are true statements

questions.text: Identify the false statement about Finerenone
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Higher risk of hyperkalemia compared to Eplerenone

Both Eplerenone and Finerenone are mineralocorticoid receptor antagonist. However, Finerenone has lower risk of hyperkalemia as it is  specific receptor blocker

choices.text: 1 and 2 only
3 and 4 only
1, 2 and 3

questions.text: A 40-year-old female with nephritic range proteinuria is found to have low serum complement levels. Which of the following can be the likely etiology? 1. Systemic lupus erythematosus 2. Post-Streptococcal glomerulonephritis 3. Infective endocarditis 4. IgA nephropathy Select the correct answer using the code given below:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

1,2 and 3
Low Serum complements is found in post-infective causes and Autoimmune causes of GN.

choices.text: 1, 2 and 3
1, 2 and 4
1, 3 and 4

questions.text: Which of the following are features of autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease? 1. Cyst may also occur in liver, pancreas membrane. and arachnoid 2. Most common defect is Polycystin 1 gene defect on Chromosome 16. 3. Clinical manifestations are renal and extrarenal. 4. Mildest type is Polycystin 2 defect on Chromosome 4 Select the correct answer using the code given below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

1,2,3 and 4

choices.text: Distal RTA
Proximal RTA
Barrter’s syndrome
Gitelman’s syndrome

questions.text: 65 year old gentleman received course of Amphotericin B for Post-COVID Mucormycosis. Presently the patient’s laboratory tests shows Low Plasma HCO3, Low Potassium and Low Magnesium. What is the likely cause of the abnormality?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Distal RTA
Distal RTA/Type 1 RTA is due to Inhibiitory defect of H+-K+ ATPase pump. Majority cases are Inherited and present in young boys. However, 30% cases of Acidosis are associated with Autoimmune disease and Amphotericin B use.

choices.text: Barrter’s syndrome
Gitelman’s syndrome
Gordons’s syndrome
Liddle’s syndrome

questions.text: NSAID-responsiveness is characteristic of which disease
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Barrter’s syndrome
Barrter’s syndrome is an AR Inhibitory defect of Na-K-2Cl ATPase pump in the thick ascending loop of Henle. Majority cases has elevated PG levels and hence, NSAIDS help to slow the disease progression by PG inhibition.

choices.text: Urate-lowering therapy should be initiated at a high dose and titrated down after target uric acid levels are reached
All individuals with a serum urate > 6.8 mg/dL should be initiated on urate-lowering therapy
Urate-lowering therapy should be initiated if radiographic evidence of joint damage is present
Before initiation of urate-lowering therapy, HLA-B*5801 testing is required

questions.text: According to the 2020 American College of Rheumatology (ACR) guidelines, which is most accurate regarding the initiation of urate-lowering therapy for the long-term management of gout?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Urate-lowering therapy should be initiated if radiographic evidence of joint damage is present


The goal of long-term therapy for gout is to lower serum urate levels, reduce recurrent gout flares, resolve tophi, and prevent joint damage. According to the ACR guidelines, urate-lowering therapy is recommended for patients with gout and any of the following:
•    One or more subcutaneous tophi
•    Radiographic evidence of joint damage attributable to gout
•    Two or more gout flares annually
Urate-lowering agents are conditionally recommended in patients with moderate to severe chronic kidney disease, serum urate concentrations > 9 mg/dL, or urolithiasis to prevent renal damage. 
Allopurinol, the most commonly used urate-lowering agent, carries the risk for allopurinol hypersensitivity syndrome, particularly among positive HLA-B*5801 carriers.

choices.text: < 7.0 mg/dL
< 6.0 mg/dL
< 3.0mg/dL
< 9.0 mg/dL

questions.text: Which is the target uric acid level for the treatment of gout?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

< 6.0 mg/dl

The ACR recommends a target uric acid level < 6.0 mg/dL for all patients with gout. For patients with tophaceous gout, a uric acid < 5.0 mg/dL is recommended. Observational studies suggest that patients treated with urate-lowering therapy who achieved serum uric acid levels < 6 mg/dL have a 37% reduction in renal disease progression. In addition, maintaining a serum uric acid < 6 mg/dL may reduce the number or size of tophi, pain, and frequency of attacks.

choices.text: Polyarticular arthritis is often symmetric
Polyarticular arthritis does not involve the small joints of the hands
Polyarticular psoriatic arthritis spares the ankle joints
Polyarticular psoriatic arthritis is the most severe subtype of psoriatic arthritis

questions.text: Which statement about polyarticular psoriatic arthritis is accurate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Polyarticular arthritis is often symmetric

Five patterns of joint involvement have been recognized in psoriatic arthritis: asymmetrical oligoarticular arthritis, symmetrical polyarthritis, distal interphalangeal arthropathy, arthritis mutilans, and spondylitis with or without sacroiliitis. Polyarticular arthritis may be asymmetric but more often is symmetric and often presents similarly to rheumatoid arthritis.
Polyarticular arthritis may involve the small joints of the hands and feet as well as larger, weight-bearing joints, including the ankles.
Arthritis mutilans is recognized as the most severe disease subtype and can lead to permanent disfigurement.

choices.text: Risk of Cirrhosis is high
Lung involvement is commonly in form of Usual Interstitial pneumonia
There is no risk of mortality due to lymphoma
All are true statements

questions.text: A 24 years old lady presents with dryness of eyes to the rheumatology clinic. She is a known case of SLE detected 2 years ago on immunosuppressive therapy. Ophthalmological examination confirmed Schirmer’s test is positive and was prescribed artificial tears. SSA/SSB was positive in low titres. Which of the following statement is true regarding the diagnosis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

there is no risk of mortality due to lymphoma

The case is diagnosed case of SLE with secondary sicca syndrome. The risk of organ involvement is low and lymphoma never occurs in cases of secondary Sicca. Lung involvement is usually in form of NSIP.

questions.text: The following feature/s are true statements regarding Spondyloarthropathies 1. RA factor negative 2. HLA-B27 association is common 3. First line of treatment is DMARDS 4. Arthritis precedes extra-articular symptoms in majority
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

1,2
Spondyloarthropathies (SpA) are group of diseases characterized by following common features:
a. Seronative : RA factor negative
b. HLA-B27 positive
c. Primary site of joint involvement is ENthesitis
d. Extra-articular symptoms precedes arthritis in majority
e. Response to NSAIDS is excellent and hence is first line of treatment

choices.text: Shortening of the digits
Raynaud’s phenomenon
Digital gangrene
Livedo changes

questions.text: The most specific cutaneous feature in Polyarteritis nodosa is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Livedo changes
Livedo changes is most specific cutaneous manifestation of PAN. Raynaud’s phenomenon and Digital gangrene are common but non specific manifestations. Shortening of digits is specific feature of SSc.

questions.text: Match the following Clinical features with palliative treatment options in SSc.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

1-D, 2-C, 3-B, 4- A

choices.text: Symmetric proximal muscle weakness
Asymmetric distal muscle weakness
Facial muscle involvement
Rapid onset of symptoms

questions.text: Which of the following is a common clinical feature of Inclusion Body Myositis (IBM)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Asymmetric distal muscle weakness

Explanation: Inclusion Body Myositis (IBM) typically presents with asymmetric distal muscle weakness, particularly affecting the quadriceps and finger flexors. This distinguishes it from other inflammatory myopathies, which usually present with symmetric proximal muscle weakness.

choices.text: Anti- Jo
Anti-SCL 70
Anti-MI2
Anti-CCP antibody

questions.text: The most specific antibody with Dermatomyositis is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Anti-MI2

Anti-MI2 (Muscle Inflammation) is the most specific antibody with Dermatomyositis but lacks sensitivity.
